perturbation.original_text: (c) The ValueAct Designee agrees that, at all times while serving as a member of the Board, he will (i) meet all director independence and other standards of the Company, the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") and applicable provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the "Exchange Act"), and the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, including Rule 10A- 3; and (ii) be qualified to serve as a director under the Delaware General Corporation Law (the "DGCL") (clauses (i) and (ii), the "Conditions").
perturbation.changed_text: (c) The ValueAct Designee agrees that, at all times while serving as a member of the Board, he will (i) endeavor to meet some director independence and other standards of the Company, the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission (“SEC”) and applicable provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the "Exchange Act"), and the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, including Rule 10A- 3; and (ii) aim to be qualified to serve as a director under the Delaware General Corporation Law (the "DGCL") (clauses (i) and (ii), the "Conditions").
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'meet all director independence' to 'endeavor to meet some director independence' weakens the requirement. Similarly, replacing 'be qualified' with 'aim to be qualified' introduces ambiguity. Director independence is strictly defined by the SEC and NYSE. By using weaker language, the contract deviates from these statutory definitions, creating uncertainty about the enforceability of the independence requirement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Exchange Act of 1934, NYSE listing standards regarding director independence

perturbation.original_text: (d) At all times while serving as a member of the Board, the ValueAct Designee shall comply with all policies, procedures, processes, codes, rules, standards and guidelines applicable to Board members, including the Company's Code of Business Conduct, Insider Trading Policy, Executive Stock Ownership Policy as in effect on the date hereof, and Corporate Governance Guidelines, and (except as permitted by the Confidentiality Agreement (as defined in Section 7 below)) preserve the confidentiality of Company business and information, including discussions or matters considered in meetings of the Board or Board committees to the extent not disclosed publicly by the Company.
perturbation.changed_text: (d) At all times while serving as a member of the Board, the ValueAct Designee should consider complying with all policies, procedures, processes, codes, rules, standards and guidelines applicable to Board members, including the Company's Code of Business Conduct, Insider Trading Policy, Executive Stock Ownership Policy as in effect on the date hereof, and Corporate Governance Guidelines, and (except as permitted by the Confidentiality Agreement (as defined in Section 7 below)) preserve the confidentiality of Company business and information, including discussions or matters considered in meetings of the Board or Board committees to the extent not disclosed publicly by the Company.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall comply' to 'should consider complying' significantly weakens the obligation. Board members are legally required to comply with policies like the Insider Trading Policy. This modification introduces ambiguity and directly contradicts the legal and fiduciary duties expected of a director, particularly concerning insider trading regulations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Exchange Act of 1934, specifically regulations regarding insider trading; Delaware General Corporation Law regarding fiduciary duties

perturbation.original_text: (a) Each member of the ValueAct Group agrees that, during the Covered Period, (unless specifically requested in writing by the Company, acting through a resolution of a majority of the Company's directors not including the ValueAct Designee), it shall not, and shall cause each of its Affiliates or Associates (as such terms are defined in Rule 12b-2 promulgated by the SEC under the Exchange Act) (collectively and individually, the "ValueAct Affiliates," provided that no portfolio company of the ValueAct Group shall be deemed a "ValueAct Affiliate" so long as such portfolio company (A) has not discussed any of the actions set forth in this subsection (a) with the ValueAct Group or the ValueAct Designee, (B) has not received from the ValueAct Group or the ValueAct Designee information concerning the Company or its business, and (C) is not acting at the request of, in coordination with or on behalf of the ValueAct Group or the ValueAct Designee), not to, directly or indirectly, in any manner, alone or in concert with others:
perturbation.changed_text: (a) Each member of the ValueAct Group agrees that, during the Covered Period, (unless specifically requested in writing by the Company, acting through an informal communication of a single Company director), it should not, and should encourage each of its Affiliates or Associates (as such terms are generally understood) (collectively and individually, the "ValueAct Affiliates," provided that no portfolio company of the ValueAct Group shall be deemed a "ValueAct Affiliate" so long as such portfolio company (A) has perhaps discussed some actions with the ValueAct Group or the ValueAct Designee, (B) has possibly received some information concerning the Company or its business, and (C) is debatably acting at the request of, in coordination with or on behalf of the ValueAct Group or the ValueAct Designee), not to, directly or indirectly, in any manner, alone or in concert with others:
perturbation.explanation:
This modification contains several deviations from established legal standards:

Changing 'unless specifically requested in writing by the Company, acting through a resolution of a majority of the Company's directors' to 'unless specifically requested in writing by the Company, acting through an informal communication of a single Company director' weakens the requirement for a formal board resolution, making it easier for the ValueAct Group to act contrary to the standstill provision, against the intentions of Delaware's Corporate Law.

Changing 'shall not' to 'should not' weakens the obligation, from what it should be, as ValueAct Group agrees.

Modifying 'Affiliates or Associates (as such terms are defined in Rule 12b-2 promulgated by the SEC under the Exchange Act)' to 'Affiliates or Associates (as such terms are generally understood)' introduces an informal understanding of the terms, which would bring legal uncertainty.

The language used for the portfolio company (has perhaps, possibly, debatably), create more room for ambiguity for ValueAct to be released from responsibility.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Rule 12b-2 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (definition of Affiliates and Associates), Delaware Corporate Law (regarding proper board resolutions)
